A hands-on guide to grasping the moon's schedule for this special Friday, October 10, 2025.
The moon's late rise on Karwa Chauth is no accident but a product of cosmic harmony. Its timing is shaped by the moon's orbit, its angle in the sky, and Earth's position.
Karwa Chauth is observed on the fourth day (Chaturthi) of the Krishna Paksha, the moon's waning phase. Just days after the full moon, it rises later in the evening.
The moon appears about 50 minutes later daily, and by the fourth waning day, this delay makes moonrise much later than it was on the full moon night.
Your exact position on Earth—latitude and longitude—dictates when the moon rises, causing variations in timing between different locations.
